awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Exact algorithms for the quantum satisfiability problem
awd_abstract_narration:
Among the most fundamental problems in theoretical computer science is the k-SATISFIABILITY problem (k-SAT), which roughly asks: Given a set of Boolean constraints of a special form, each acting on k out of n bits, does there exist an assignment to all n bits which simultaneously satisfies every constraint? This problem has far-reaching applications in areas ranging from artificial intelligence to electronic design automation to theorem proving, thus underscoring its significance. 

More recently, a quantum generalization of k-SAT has arisen, known as k-QSAT, which finds applications in areas such as quantum error-correcting codes. Moreover, k-QSAT is physically well-motivated, as it can be thought of as modeling how quantum systems in nature are governed by local quantum constraints. Unlike k-SAT, however, much less is known about k-QSAT. The aim of this project is precisely to close this fundamental knowledge gap. In particular, this project broadly asks: In what cases can non-trivial algorithms be developed for solving k-QSAT? 

The resolution of this question will yield deep insights into which properties of quantum systems can be computed efficiently by a classical computer. Moreover, the results obtained will be disseminated through a variety of avenues, including conferences, new course materials, and high school workshops aimed at exposing young computer scientists to the frontiers of research.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the complexity of the Quantum Satisfiability Problem (k-QSAT). Roughly, this problem aims to study certain properties of quantum many-body systems which are cooled to low temperatures (typically near absolute zero). The research produced a number of results, of which we list the most two significant ones below:

  1. It was previously known that when quantum systems interact in pairs (2-QSAT), the problem considered can be "efficiently" solved by a classical computer. However, the previous known algorithm was quartic time, making it infeasible in practice. Funded by this grant, the PI and collaborators developed an optimal linear time classical algorithm for 2-QSAT.
  2. When quantum systems interact in triplets (3-QSAT), it was known that the problem considered is intractable. The PI and collaborators developed a novel "parameterized" algorithm for 3-QSAT, which utilizes new tools from a branch of mathematics known as algebraic geometry, and which founds the new area of study of parameterized algorithms for k-QSAT.

This research was presented at established conferences around the globe, in countries such as Canada, Germany, Japan, the UK, and the USA.

In terms of teaching and training, this grant funded the training of a female Ph.D. candidate, as well an undergraduate research assistant.

Regarding outreach, under this grant the PI annually organized and hosted a computer science outreach event at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) known as CS Day. This event drew roughly 70 high school students from across Virginia to VCU to learn about advanced topics in computer science beyond what is normally taught in the classroom. Both research and industry perspectives were presented, as well as high school summer research interniship opportunities at VCU and information on hackathons.
